feed.title: Google Cloud: Artifact Registry
feed.subtitle: Changelog for Google Cloud product: Artifact Registry

entry.content: Artifact Registry is available in the asia-southeast3 region (Bangkok). For more information, see Global locations.
entry.summary: Artifact Registry is now available in the asia-southeast3 region, located in Bangkok. This expansion brings our artifact management services closer to developers in Southeast Asia, improving performance and reducing latency. For a full list of supported regions, please visit our global locations page.
entry.title: Feature: Artifact Registry now in Bangkok

entry.content: Artifact Registry now calculates fingerprints for each version of a package pushed to the Artifact Registry repository. You can use the fingerprint to validate that the package wasn't modified when moving between Google Cloud systems, such as Compute Engine and Cloud Build. This feature is in public preview. For more information, see Use fingerprints to verify package version identities.
entry.summary: Artifact Registry now calculates fingerprints for each package version. This allows you to verify that packages remain unmodified when moved between Google Cloud systems, ensuring integrity and security.
entry.title: Feature: Package fingerprinting in Artifact Registry

entry.content: You can now use ExportArtifact() to export an artifact to a Cloud Storage bucket.
entry.summary: You can now use ExportArtifact() to export an artifact to a Cloud Storage bucket.
entry.title: Feature: Export Artifacts to Cloud Storage

entry.content:
Artifact Registry support for managing Ruby gems with Artifact Registry repositories is in Preview. For more information, see the following topics:

  • Get started with Ruby gems
  • Store Ruby gems in Artifact Registry (Quickstart)
entry.summary: You can now manage Ruby gems using Artifact Registry repositories. This feature is in Preview, and you can learn more by reviewing the "Get started with Ruby gems" and "Store Ruby gems in Artifact Registry" documentation.
entry.title: Feature: Artifact Registry support for Ruby gems now in Preview

entry.content:
Layer-based scanning for Artifact Analysis is in Preview. You can view vulnerability metadata for a specific layer of your image digest in the Google Cloud Console and in the GCloud CLI. For more information, see the following topics:

Google Cloud Console:

  • View layer metadata for Go images
  • View layer metadata for Java images
  • View layer metadata for Node.js images
  • View layer metadata for Python images

GCloud CLI

  • View layer metadata for Go images
  • View layer metadata for Java images
  • View layer metadata for Node.js images
  • View layer metadata for Python images
entry.summary: Artifact Analysis now supports layer-based scanning, allowing you to view vulnerability metadata for specific layers of your container images in the Google Cloud Console and GCloud CLI. This feature is currently in Preview.
entry.title: Feature: Layer-based scanning for Artifact Analysis now in Preview

entry.content:
The Container Analysis API now supports the option of returning partial results during region-down failure conditions when listing notes, listing occurrences, or generating vulnerability summaries. For more information, view the returnPartialSuccess parameter for the following requests:

  • v1.projects.locations.notes.list
  • v1.projects.locations.occurrences.getVulnerabilitySummary
  • v1.projects.locations.occurrences.list
  • v1.projects.notes.list
  • v1.projects.occurrences.getVulnerabilitySummary
  • v1.projects.occurrences.list
  • v1beta1.projects.locations.notes.list
  • v1beta1.projects.locations.occurrences.getVulnerabilitySummary
  • v1beta1.projects.locations.occurrences.list
  • v1beta1.projects.notes.list
  • v1beta1.projects.occurrences.getVulnerabilitySummary
  • v1beta1.projects.occurrences.list
entry.summary: The Container Analysis API now supports partial results when encountering regional failures during note and occurrence listings, and vulnerability summary generation. This enhancement aims to improve reliability by allowing operations to complete even if some data cannot be retrieved.
entry.title: Changed: Partial results for Container Analysis API

entry.content:
Artifact Registry generic repositories are now generally available.

Generic repositories store versioned, immutable artifacts that don't have to adhere to any specific package format in Artifact Registry. You can store and manage arbitrary files such as archives, binaries, and media files with no package specifications or management clients.

To get started with generic repositories, see the quickstart.
entry.summary: Artifact Registry generic repositories are now available. You can use them to store and manage arbitrary files like archives, binaries, and media files without needing specific package formats or management clients.
entry.title: Announcement: Artifact Registry generic repositories now generally available
